[The Championships, Wimbledon](/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The
Championships, Wimbledon") is an annual [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis")
tournament first contested in [1877](/wiki/1877_Wimbledon_Championship "1877
Wimbledon Championship") and played on [outdoor grass
courts](/wiki/Grass_court "Grass court")[a][b][1] at the [All England Lawn
Tennis and Croquet Club](/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club "All
England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club") (AELTC) in the
[Wimbledon](/wiki/Wimbledon,_London "Wimbledon, London") suburb of London,
United Kingdom.[2] The Ladies' Singles was started in
[1884](/wiki/1884_Wimbledon_Championships "1884 Wimbledon Championships").[3]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Wimbledon_ladies%27_singles_champions&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Wimbledon has historically been played in the last week of June and the first
week of July (though changed to the first two weeks of July in 2017), and has
been chronologically the third of the four [Grand
Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(tennis\) "Grand Slam \(tennis\)") tournaments of the
tennis [season](/wiki/Season_\(sports\) "Season \(sports\)") since 1987.[2]
The event was not held from 1915 to 1918 because of [World War
I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") and again from 1940 to 1945 because of
[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[4]

The Ladies' Singles' rules have undergone several changes since the first
edition. From [1886](/wiki/1886_Wimbledon_Championships "1886 Wimbledon
Championships") until [1921](/wiki/1921_Wimbledon_Championships "1921
Wimbledon Championships"), the event started with a [knockout](/wiki/Single-
elimination_tournament "Single-elimination tournament") phase, the All Comers'
Singles, whose winner then faced the defending champion in a [challenge
round](/wiki/Glossary_of_tennis#Challenge_Round "Glossary of tennis"). The All
Comers' winner was automatically awarded the title six times
([1887](/wiki/1887_Wimbledon_Championships "1887 Wimbledon Championships"),
[1891](/wiki/1891_Wimbledon_Championships "1891 Wimbledon Championships"),
[1895](/wiki/1895_Wimbledon_Championships "1895 Wimbledon Championships"),
[1907](/wiki/1907_Wimbledon_Championships "1907 Wimbledon Championships"),
[1908](/wiki/1908_Wimbledon_Championships "1908 Wimbledon Championships")) in
the absence of the previous year's champion. The challenge round system was
abolished with the [1922](/wiki/1922_Wimbledon_Championships "1922 Wimbledon
Championships") edition.[5] Since the first championships, all matches have
been played at the [best-of-three sets](/wiki/Tennis_score#Scoring_a_set
"Tennis score"). Between 1877 and [1883](/wiki/1883_Wimbledon_Championship
"1883 Wimbledon Championship"), the winner of the next game at five
games[-all](/wiki/Glossary_of_tennis#All "Glossary of tennis") took the set in
every match except the All Comers' final, and the challenge round, which were
won with six games and a two games advantage. All sets were decided in two-
game [advantage format](/wiki/Glossary_of_tennis#Advantage_format "Glossary of
tennis") from [1884](/wiki/1884_Wimbledon_Championships "1884 Wimbledon
Championships") to [1970](/wiki/1970_Wimbledon_Championships "1970 Wimbledon
Championships").[5] The [lingering
death](/wiki/Glossary_of_tennis#Lingering_death "Glossary of tennis") best-
of-12 points [tie-break](/wiki/Tennis_score#Scoring_a_tiebreak_game "Tennis
score") was introduced in [1971](/wiki/1971_Wimbledon_Championships "1971
Wimbledon Championships") for the first two sets, played at eight games-all
until [1978](/wiki/1978_Wimbledon_Championships "1978 Wimbledon
Championships") and at six games-all since
[1979](/wiki/1979_Wimbledon_Championships "1979 Wimbledon
Championships").[5][6][7]

The Ladies' Singles champion receives a sterling silver salver commonly known
as the "[Venus Rosewater Dish](/wiki/Venus_Rosewater_Dish "Venus Rosewater
Dish")", or simply the "Rosewater Dish". The salver, which is 18.75 inches
(about 48 cm) in diameter, is decorated with figures from mythology.[8] New
singles champions are traditionally elected honorary members of the AELTC by
the club's committee.[c][9] In 2012, the Ladies' Singles winner received
[prize money](/wiki/Prize_money "Prize money") of [£](/wiki/Pound_sterling
"Pound sterling")1,150,000.[10]

These records include the Amateur Era only, [Dorothea Lambert
Chambers](/wiki/Dorothea_Lambert_Chambers "Dorothea Lambert Chambers")
(1903–1904, 1906, 1910–1911, 1913–1914) holds the record for most titles, with
seven, and [Lottie Dod](/wiki/Lottie_Dod "Lottie Dod") (1891–1893) and
[Suzanne Lenglen](/wiki/Suzanne_Lenglen "Suzanne Lenglen") (1919–1921) holds
the record for most consecutive wins in the Ladies' Singles during the
challenge round era, with three victories each. The record for most
consecutive and most wins post challenge round during the Amateur Era is
[Helen Wills Moody](/wiki/Helen_Wills_Moody "Helen Wills Moody") (1927–1930),
with four straight wins, and Moody holds the record for most victories in this
era with eight (1927–1930, 1932–1933, 1935, 1938).[4]

These records only include the Open Era, since the inclusion of the
professional tennis players, [Martina Navratilova](/wiki/Martina_Navratilova
"Martina Navratilova") (1978–1979, 1982–1987, 1990) holds the record for most
victories with nine. Navratilova holds the record for most consecutive
victories with six (1982–1987).[4]

This event has been won without the loss of a set, during the Open Era of
Tennis, by the following players: [Billie Jean King](/wiki/Billie_Jean_King
"Billie Jean King") in 1968, 1972, 1973 and 1975, [Margaret
Court](/wiki/Margaret_Court "Margaret Court") in 1970, [Evonne Goolagong
Cawley](/wiki/Evonne_Goolagong_Cawley "Evonne Goolagong Cawley") in 1971 and
1980, [Chris Evert](/wiki/Chris_Evert "Chris Evert") in 1974 and 1981,
[Martina Navratilova](/wiki/Martina_Navratilova "Martina Navratilova") in
1979, 1983, 1984, 1986, 1987, and 1990, [Steffi Graf](/wiki/Steffi_Graf
"Steffi Graf") in 1992 and 1996, [Jana Novotná](/wiki/Jana_Novotn%C3%A1 "Jana
Novotná") in 1998, [Lindsay Davenport](/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport "Lindsay
Davenport") in 1999, [Venus Williams](/wiki/Venus_Williams "Venus Williams")
in 2000, 2007 and 2008, [Serena Williams](/wiki/Serena_Williams "Serena
Williams") in 2002, 2009, 2010, 2015 and 2016, [Maria
Sharapova](/wiki/Maria_Sharapova "Maria Sharapova") in 2004, [Petra
Kvitová](/wiki/Petra_Kvitov%C3%A1 "Petra Kvitová") in 2011 and 2014 and
[Marion Bartoli](/wiki/Marion_Bartoli "Marion Bartoli") in 2013.

[Lottie Dod](/wiki/Lottie_Dod "Lottie Dod") was a five-time champion and is
the youngest ever winner of the ladies' singles championships (15 years and
285 days).

[![A black and white picture, a woman is in all-white attire with a tie on,
and is looking right at the camera in the photograph with a racket in her
right
hand](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Charlotte_Cooper.jpg/150px-

[](/wiki/File:Charlotte_Cooper.jpg "Enlarge")

[Charlotte Cooper Sterry](/wiki/Charlotte_Cooper_\(tennis\) "Charlotte Cooper
\(tennis\)") was a five-time champion and is the oldest ladies’ singles
champion (37 year and 282 days).

[![A black and white picture, a woman is in all-white attire hitting a right-
handed one handed backhand with a racket in her right
hand](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Dorothea_Douglass.jpg/150px-
Dorothea_Douglass.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dorothea_Douglass.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dorothea_Douglass.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dorothea Lambert Chambers](/wiki/Dorothea_Douglass_Lambert_Chambers "Dorothea
Douglass Lambert Chambers") was a seven-time champion between 1903 and 1914.

[![A woman looking at the camera with a coloured bandanna on and a white
shirt, which this picture is black and
white](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Suzanne_Lenglen_02.jpg/150px-
Suzanne_Lenglen_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Suzanne_Lenglen_02.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Suzanne_Lenglen_02.jpg "Enlarge")

[Suzanne Lenglen](/wiki/Suzanne_Lenglen "Suzanne Lenglen") was a six-time
champion.

[![A woman looking away from the camera with a tennis racket in her right hand
and a colored sweater on and all white clothing, which this picture is a black
and
white](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-07878%2C_Helen_Wills_Moody.jpg/150px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-07878%2C_Helen_Wills_Moody.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-07878,_Helen_Wills_Moody.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-07878,_Helen_Wills_Moody.jpg "Enlarge")

[Helen Wills Moody](/wiki/Helen_Wills_Moody "Helen Wills Moody") was an eight-
time champion between 1927 and 1938.

[![A woman looking and smiling toward the
camera](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Maureen_Connolly_1953.jpg/150px-
Maureen_Connolly_1953.jpg)](/wiki/File:Maureen_Connolly_1953.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Maureen_Connolly_1953.jpg "Enlarge")

[Maureen Connolly](/wiki/Maureen_Connolly "Maureen Connolly") competed in
1952, 1953 and 1954 and won the title on all three occasions.

[![A woman looking toward the camera with a tennis racket held diagonally in
front of
her.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Althea_Gibson_NYWTS.jpg/150px-
Althea_Gibson_NYWTS.jpg)](/wiki/File:Althea_Gibson_NYWTS.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Althea_Gibson_NYWTS.jpg "Enlarge")

[Althea Gibson](/wiki/Althea_Gibson "Althea Gibson") won the title in 1957,
the first tennis player of colour to do so, and successfully defended her
title in 1958.

Billie_Jean_King_by_David_Shankbone.jpg)](/wiki/File:Billie_Jean_King_by_David_Shankbone.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Billie_Jean_King_by_David_Shankbone.jpg "Enlarge")

[Billie Jean King](/wiki/Billie_Jean_King "Billie Jean King") is a six-time
champion overall and a four-time champion in the open era.

[![A blond-haired women with a white shirt, black shorts, and white tennis
shoes on about ready to serve the tennis ball in
hand](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Navratilova-
PragueOpen2006-05_cropped.jpg/150px-Navratilova-
PragueOpen2006-05_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Navratilova-
PragueOpen2006-05_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Navratilova-PragueOpen2006-05_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

[Martina Navratilova](/wiki/Martina_Navratilova "Martina Navratilova") is a
nine-time singles champion, an all-time [Grand
Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(tennis\) "Grand Slam \(tennis\)") record in the Open
Era for women (Margaret Court won the Australian 11 times). She won six
consecutive titles from 1982 to 1987.

[![A blond-haired women wearing a white
shirt](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Steffi_Graf_08.jpg/150px-
Steffi_Graf_08.jpg)](/wiki/File:Steffi_Graf_08.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Steffi_Graf_08.jpg "Enlarge")

[Steffi Graf](/wiki/Steffi_Graf "Steffi Graf") is a seven-time champion over a
nine-year period from 1988 to 1996.

[![A black woman wearing a white ensemble with purple accents and
headband](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Wimbledon_2012_Day_10_Cropped.jpg/150px-
Wimbledon_2012_Day_10_Cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wimbledon_2012_Day_10_Cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wimbledon_2012_Day_10_Cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

[Serena Williams](/wiki/Serena_Williams "Serena Williams") is a seven-time
champion.

[![A black woman is serving the ball, and is wearing a white sleeveless top
and blue
skirt](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Venus_Williams_WTT.jpg/150px-
Venus_Williams_WTT.jpg)](/wiki/File:Venus_Williams_WTT.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Venus_Williams_WTT.jpg "Enlarge")

[Venus Williams](/wiki/Venus_Williams "Venus Williams") is a five-time
champion.

##
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_Wimbledon_ladies%27_singles_champions&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Notes")]

  * **a** Since 2009, [Centre Court](/wiki/Centre_Court "Centre Court") features a [retractable roof](/wiki/Retractable_roof "Retractable roof"), allowing [indoor](/wiki/Tennis_court#Indoor_courts "Tennis court") and night-time play.[12]
  * **b** Wimbledon entered the [Open Era](/wiki/History_of_tennis#Open_Era "History of tennis") with the [1968](/wiki/1968_Wimbledon_Championships "1968 Wimbledon Championships") edition, allowing [professional](/wiki/Professional "Professional") players to compete alongside [amateurs](/wiki/Amateur "Amateur").[3]
  * **c** [John McEnroe](/wiki/John_McEnroe "John McEnroe") is the only player to have been denied membership in [1981](/wiki/1981_Wimbledon_Championships "1981 Wimbledon Championships"), because of his on-court behaviour during the championships.[13][14]
  * **d** Each year is linked to an article about that particular year's draws, but pre-1922 they did not have draws due to the challenge round system. In 1922 till the present they do have draws, but the years of 1925–1939 do not have draw pages with links, so it is linked to the year's articles instead.
  * **e** "British Isles" (BRI) is used for players from the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland") (1801–1922), distinct from "Great Britain" (GBR) used for players from the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Northern_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland") (1922–present).[4][15]
  * **f** The tournament was not held from 1915 to 1918 because of World War I.[4]
  * **g** The tournament was not held from 1940 to 1945 because of World War II.[4]
  * **h** [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia "Czechoslovakia") (TCH, 1918–1992) split into the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic "Czech Republic") (CZE, 1992–present) and [Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia") (SVK, 1992–present).
  * **i** [Martina Navratilova](/wiki/Martina_Navratilova "Martina Navratilova") was born in Czechoslovakia, but was stripped of her citizenship in 1975 when she defected to the United States. She became a US citizen in 1981.[16]
  * **j** FRG is West Germany, but after unification became just Germany (GER) after 1990.
